# Importing the necessary libraries
import matplotlib.pyplot as plt
import seaborn as sns
import plotly.express as px
import plotly.graph_objects as go
from plotly.subplots import make_subplots
import plotly.io as pio
import glob
import datetime as dt
from wordcloud import WordCloud
%matplotlib inline
import warnings
warnings.filterwarnings("ignore")

from scipy.stats import boxcox
from statsmodels.graphics.tsaplots import plot_acf, plot_pacf
from statsmodels.tsa.statespace.sarimax import SARIMAX
from datetime import timedelta
from sklearn.metrics import mean_squared_error

from pylab import rcParams
import statsmodels.api as sm

# Defining the templates for seaborn, matplotlib and plotly
pio.templates.default = "plotly_white"

plt.style.use("seaborn-paper")
plt.rc("figure", autolayout=True)
plt.rc("font", **{"family":"Comic Sans MS"})
plt.rc(
    "axes",
    labelweight="bold",
    labelsize="large",
    titleweight="bold",
    titlesize=16,
    titlepad=10,

source.7f6efb18:
def count_plot(dataframe, feature): if len(feature)==1 and dataframe[feature[0]].nunique()<6: fig = px.bar(x=dataframe[feature[0]].value_counts().index, y=dataframe[feature[0]].value_counts().values) fig.update_layout(font_family="Comic Sans MS") fig.update_xaxes(tickangle=270, title=None, tickfont_size=16) fig.update_yaxes(title="Counts") return fig else: fig = px.bar(y=dataframe[feature[0]].value_counts().index, x=dataframe[feature[0]].value_counts().values, orientation="h") fig.update_layout(font_family="Comic Sans MS") fig.update_xaxes(title="Counts", tickfont_size=14) fig.update_yaxes(title=None) return fig def bar_plot(dataframe, feature1, feature2): if len(feature2)>1: fig = make_subplots(rows=1, cols=len(feature2), subplot_titles=feature2) for i in range(len(feature2)): fig.add_trace(go.Bar(x=dataframe[feature1[0]], y=dataframe[feature2[i]], name=feature2[i]), row=1, col=i+1) fig.update_layout(font_family="Comic Sans MS", showlegend=False, margin=dict(l=0, r=0, t=100, b=50), height=400) return fig def pie_plot(dataframe, feature): fig = go.Figure() fig.add_trace(go.Pie(values=dataframe[feature].value_counts().values, labels=dataframe[feature].value_counts().index, pull=[0,0.1,0,0.1],textinfo='percent+value')) fig.update_layout(font_family="Comic Sans MS", margin=dict(t=100, b=50)) return fig def map_plot(dataframe, location, color, hover): fig = px.choropleth(data_frame=dataframe, locations=location, locationmode="USA-states", color=color, scope="usa", hover_name=hover, color_continuous_scale="viridis_r") fig.update_layout(font_family="Comic Sans MS",) return fig def path_plot(dataframe, path, values, plot_type): if plot_type=="treemap": fig = px.treemap(data_frame=dataframe, path=path, values=values, color_discrete_sequence=px.colors.qualitative.G10) fig.update_layout(font_family="Comic Sans MS", font_size=16, margin=dict(t=50, b=0)) return fig elif plot_type=="sunburst": fig = px.sunburst(data_frame=dataframe, path=path, values=values, color_discrete_sequence=px.colors.qualitative.G10) fig.update_layout(font_family="Comic Sans MS", font_size=16, margin=dict(t=50, b=0)) return fig def time_plot(df, factor, label): for i in ["pct_access","engagement_index"]: fig = px.line(data_frame=df, x="week", y=i, color=factor) fig.update_layout(font_family="Comic Sans MS",title=dict(text=""+i+" - "+factor+" wise - "+label, x=0.5, font_size=20), height=300, margin=dict(b=0)) fig.update_xaxes(title=None) fig.update_yaxes(title=None) fig.show() def comparison_bar_plot(df): fig = make_subplots(rows=1, cols=2, shared_yaxes=True, horizontal_spacing=0.01, subplot_titles=["Based on PCT Access", "Based on Enagagement Index"]) fig.add_trace(go.Bar(x=df["pct_access"], y=df["Product Name"], text=df.pct_rank, textposition="outside",orientation="h"), row=1, col=1) fig.add_trace(go.Bar(x=df.engagement_index, y=df["Product Name"], text=df.engagement_rank, textposition="outside", orientation="h"), row=1, col=2) fig.add_annotation(x=250000000, y=3, font_size=16, text="Number over the Bars
depicts their Overall Rank in
Products List", row=1, col=2, showarrow=False) return fig def month_map_comparison(df, name): months_map = {1:"January",2:"February",3:"March",4:"April", 5:"May",6:"June",7:"July",8:"August",9:"September", 10:"October",11:"November",12:"December"} temp = df.copy() temp["month"] = temp.time.dt.month temp = temp.groupby(["state","state_code","month"])[["pct_access","engagement_index"]].mean().reset_index() temp["Month_2020"] = temp.month.map(months_map) pct_min = temp.pct_access.min() pct_max = np.round(temp.pct_access.max(),0) #pct_access over the time fig = px.choropleth(data_frame=temp, locations="state_code", locationmode="USA-states", color="pct_access", scope="usa", color_continuous_scale="Portland_r", animation_frame="Month_2020", hover_name="state", \ range_color=[pct_min, pct_max]) fig.update_layout(font_family="Comic Sans MS", title=dict(text="PCT Access over Time - "+name, font_size=20, x=0.5)) fig.show() eng_min = temp.engagement_index.min() eng_max = np.round(temp.engagement_index.max(),0) # Enagagement Index over the time fig = px.choropleth(data_frame=temp, locations="state_code", locationmode="USA-states", color="engagement_index", scope="usa", color_continuous_scale="Portland_r", animation_frame="Month_2020", hover_name="state", range_color=[eng_min, eng_max]) fig.update_layout(font_family="Comic Sans MS", title=dict(text="Engagement Index over Time - "+name, font_size=20, x=0.5)) fig.show() def time_analysis(df, title): df2 = pd.Series(boxcox(df, lmbda=0), index=df.index) train = df2.iloc[:301] test = df2.iloc[301:] model = SARIMAX(train, order=(1,1,1), seasonal_order=(1,1,1,14), exog=holiday.iloc[:301]).fit() predictions = df.copy() predictions["forecast_box_cox"] = model.predict(df.index.max(), holiday.index.max(), exog=holiday.loc[test.index.min():holiday.index.max()]) predictions["forecast"] = np.exp(predictions["forecast_box_cox"]) fig = go.Figure() fig.add_trace(go.Scatter(x=df.index, y=df.values, name="Original")) fig.add_trace(go.Scatter(x=predictions["forecast"].index, y=predictions["forecast"].values, name="Forecast", line_color="lightblue")) fig.update_layout(title=dict(text=title, font_size=20, x=0.5, font_family="Comic Sans MS"), margin=dict(b=20, t=50, r=0), height=400) fig.show()

source.26d6bbf5:
# importing household income table from below url
household_income = pd.read_html("https://fred.stlouisfed.org/release/tables?eid=259515&rid=249")[0]

# extracting useful data
household_income.columns = ["unknown","state","Income","preceding_period","year_ago_period"]    #renaming the columns
household_income.drop(["unknown","preceding_period","year_ago_period"], axis=1, inplace=True)    #removing not reuired features
household_income.replace("District of Columbia","District Of Columbia", inplace=True)
household_income.head()
source.dc1785fc:
# Poverty level of States - using information from wikipedia - using below url
poverty = pd.read_html("https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/List_of_U.S._states_and_territories_by_poverty_rate")[1]

# Extracting useful columns from the poverty and cleaning it
poverty.columns = ["rank","state","poverty_rate","poverty_rate_2014","poverty_measure"]    #renaming the columns
poverty.drop(["rank","poverty_rate_2014","poverty_measure"], axis=1, inplace=True)        #droppimg not so reuired columns
poverty.replace("District of Columbia","District Of Columbia", inplace=True)

# cleaning the poverty percentage column
poverty.poverty_rate = poverty.poverty_rate.apply(lambda x: float(x.split("%")[0]))    #cleaning the poverty_rate column
poverty.head()

# combining the dataframes

districts = pd.merge(districts, household_income, how="left", on="state")    #merging household income with districts
districts.head()

source.ce99a7fb:
# function for extracting the average of the values from the ranges
def avg_ranges(x):
    return np.array(str(x).strip("[").split(",")).astype(float).mean()

# Creating the averages for all ranges columns
districts['avg_black_hispanic'] = districts['pct_black/hispanic'].apply(avg_ranges)
districts['avg_reduced_lunch'] = districts['pct_free/reduced'].apply(avg_ranges)
districts['avg_spent_per_pupil'] = districts['pp_total_raw'].apply(avg_ranges)


# dropping the range columns
districts.drop(["pct_black/hispanic",'pct_free/reduced','pp_total_raw'], axis=1, inplace=True)
districts.head()

source.75189f08:
# Temporary Dataframe for Checking the Distribution of Locale in every State
temp = pd.crosstab(districts.state, districts.locale)
temp["summation"] = temp.sum(axis=1)
temp["city_percent"] = temp.City*100/temp.summation
temp["rural_percent"] = temp.Rural*100/temp.summation
temp["suburb_percent"] = temp.Suburb*100/temp.summation
temp["town_percent"] = temp.Town*100/temp.summation

# State and locale Distribution Plot
fig = go.Figure()
fig.add_trace(go.Bar(x=temp.index, y=temp.city_percent, name="Percentage City"))
fig.add_trace(go.Bar(x=temp.index, y=temp.rural_percent, name="Percentage Rural"))
fig.add_trace(go.Bar(x=temp.index, y=temp.suburb_percent, name="Percentage Suburb"))
fig.add_trace(go.Bar(x=temp.index, y=temp.town_percent, name="Percentage Town"))

# fig.update_traces(texttemplate='%{text:.2s}')
fig.update_xaxes(tickfont_size=16, tickangle=270)
fig.update_layout(font_family="Comic Sans MS", title=dict(text="<b>Locale Distribution per State", font_size=20, x=0.5),
                  barmode='stack', height=600,
                  legend=dict(orientation="h",
                              yanchor="bottom",
                              y=1.02,xanchor="right",
                              x=1
                ))
fig.show()
del temp

source.f95ed8e0:
# Gropued Data for States
grouped_districts = districts.groupby(by=["state"])[['avg_black_hispanic','avg_reduced_lunch','avg_spent_per_pupil',
                                                    "poverty_rate","Income"]].mean()

# Cretaing Variables for computing Averages across various States
grouped_districts["above_avg_hispanic"] = grouped_districts.avg_black_hispanic.apply(lambda x: 1 if x>grouped_districts.avg_black_hispanic.mean() else 0)
grouped_districts["above_avg_lunch"] = grouped_districts.avg_reduced_lunch.apply(lambda x: 1 if x>grouped_districts.avg_reduced_lunch.mean() else 0)
grouped_districts["above_avg_pupil"] = grouped_districts.avg_spent_per_pupil.apply(lambda x: 1 if x>grouped_districts.avg_spent_per_pupil.mean() else 0)
grouped_districts["above_poverty_line"] = grouped_districts.poverty_rate.apply(lambda x: 1 if x>grouped_districts.poverty_rate.mean() else 0)
grouped_districts["above_household_income"] = grouped_districts.Income.apply(lambda x: 1 if x>grouped_districts.Income.mean() else 0)

grouped_districts.head()

source.f666f11d:
# Function for creating Sub_Category feature
def sub_category(x):
    a = str(x).split("-")
    if len(a)<2:
        return x
    else:
        return "-".join(a[1:])

# biufurcating the Primary Essential Column into Category and Sub_Category
products["Category"] = products["Primary Essential Function"].apply(lambda x: str(x).split("-")[0])
products["Sub_Category"] = products["Primary Essential Function"].apply(sub_category)

# Segrregating the Sub-Categories
products["Sub_Category"] = products["Sub_Category"].apply(lambda x: str(x).split("-")[0])

# Replacing the string type nan values in Category and Sub-Category columns with np.nan 
products[["Category","Sub_Category"]] = products[["Category","Sub_Category"]].replace("nan",np.nan)
products.head()

source.79f53475:
# /kaggle/input/learnplatform-covid19-impact-on-digital-learning/
# the Engagement Dataframe
path = r"/kaggle/input/learnplatform-covid19-impact-on-digital-learning/engagement_data"
filenames = glob.glob(path+"/*.csv")

engagement = pd.DataFrame()
for file in filenames:
    b = pd.read_csv(file)
    b["district_id"] = int(file.split("/")[-1].split(".")[0])
    engagement = pd.concat([engagement,b])

engagement.reset_index(drop=True)
engagement.head()

# temp dataframe for computing enagement index and pct_access across all USA. temp = engagement.groupby("time")[["engagement_index","pct_access"]].mean().reset_index() # Plot showing overall enegamenet index and pct _access fig = make_subplots(rows=2, cols=1, shared_xaxes=True, vertical_spacing=0.1, subplot_titles=["% Atleast 1 page Load Event

#State wise affect of Covid on Page Load events - best performing states
temp = df.groupby(["state","week"])[["pct_access","engagement_index"]].mean().reset_index()
temp = temp[~temp.state.isin(["Minnesota","North Dakota"])]           # data is not complete for these states

top_10_states = temp.groupby(["state"])["engagement_index"].sum().reset_index().sort_values("engagement_index",ascending=False).head(10).state.values

temp = temp[temp.state.isin(top_10_states)]

time_plot(temp, "state", "Top 10")

temp = df.groupby(["week"])[["pct_access","engagement_index"]].mean().reset_index()

for i in ["pct_access","engagement_index"]:
    fig = go.Figure()
    fig.add_trace(go.Scatter(x=temp.week, y=temp[i], name="USA Average", mode='lines'))

    fig.update_layout(height=250, margin=dict(b=0, r=0, t=50), 
                      title=dict(text="North Dakota vs USA - "+i, x=0.5, font_size=20, font_family="Comic Sans MS"))
    fig.show()

source.6353ec3e:
engagement = df.groupby("time")["engagement_index"].mean()

# creating a dataframe for holidays in schools 
holiday = pd.DataFrame(columns=["Date"])
holiday.Date = engagement.index

for i in range(366, 366+181):
    holiday.loc[i] = holiday.loc[i-1,]+timedelta(days=1)
    
holiday["holiday"] = holiday.Date.apply(lambda x: 1 if (x>dt.datetime(2021,6,20) and x<dt.datetime(2021,8,10)) 
                                        or (x>dt.datetime(2020,6,20) and x<dt.datetime(2020,8,9))
                                        or (x.month==12 and x.day>24) 
                                        or (x.month==1 and x.day<2) 
                                        or (x>dt.datetime(2020,11,26) and x<dt.datetime(2020,11,28)) else 0)
holiday = holiday.set_index("Date")

From above Forecastings we can see that engagement level and pct_access will increase in year 2021. Although, it might have some dips during the holidays seasons but it is having a increasing trend. Introduction of vaccines and many peoples getting vaccinated which might result in reopening of schools which might affect the digital learning platforms/products.
For the year 2020, may states stated emphasizing on digital learning products, as a results these products gained popularity over the time. Some states also started implementing policies to encourage students/teachers to adopt digital platforms for teaching in covid era. If COVID-19 does not ease in year 2021. The similar increasing will be observed in 2021 also, with probable forecast as seen above.

source.eaff7ac5:
Google Classroom is the most poplar product for SDO category. Schools prefered to teach their children on Google Classroom in lockdowns. ClassLink, Clever and Google Sites are also among top products.
On other Hand, Google Docs is the most popular product under Learning Curriculum category. Students like to share their notes or study material over google docs. Youtube, and Canvas are also popular among LC category. Youtube providing lots of video material for free to students.

Lastly we have another Category called Classroom Management(CM). Lets look at the top products in CM category and their standing in overall products list.

source.a1fd72df:
What is the effect of the COVID-19 pandemic on online and distance learning, and how might this also evolve in the future?
For answering this question, Lets import some Covid Data
source.ac20d5a6:
F. The PRODUCTS data

The product file includes information about the characteristics of the top 372 products with most users in 2020. The categories listed in this file are part of LearnPlatform's product taxonomy.
source.54aac756:
How does student engagement with different types of education technology change over the course of the pandemic?
For this, we have seen that School and District Operations (SDO) Products were the most favoured products among the students. Some of the Top Products under SDO category are Google Classroom, Clever, other Google sites, Classlink , Schoology. After starting of Lockdowns, schools used these sites to teach/guide the students. However, Classroom Management(CM) products gained popularity over the course of covid period in 2020 specially at later phase. Some of the Popular Products among this category were Google Forms, Meet, Zoom, hangouts etc. These platforms provide much interactive features while teaching/discussions between teachers and students. Therefore, teachers preferred these products for interacting with their students.
It can be seen that during the holidays like summer break, thanksgiving holidays, winter break etc. there was a significant drop in Engagement level of Students and teachers.

Now lets have a look at another important aspect.
source.980f1061:
Observations about Districts data:-

  1. Most Districts belong to Connecticut followed by Utah and Massachusetts.
  2. Most of Data is about the suburb locale.
  3. Florida, Michigan, Minnesota, New Jersey and Wisconsin have 100% suburbs coverage.
  4. On other hand Arizona, District of Columbia have 100% of the data about City.
  5. lastly, New Hamsphire and North Dakota have Rural coverage only.

source.f5e71d73:
A. Introduction

Nelson Mandela believed education was the most powerful weapon to change the world. But not every student has equal opportunities to learn. Effective policies and plans need to be enacted in order to make education more equitable—and perhaps your innovative data analysis will help reveal the solution.

Current research shows educational outcomes are far from equitable. The imbalance was exacerbated by the COVID-19 pandemic. There's an urgent need to better understand and measure the scope and impact of the pandemic on these inequities.
source.4024c783: Students whom are eligible for free reduced lunch are based on average household incomes. Students who belong to household where income is 130% or below poverty are eligible for free lunches. On other hand Students who belong to household with income from 130% to 185% of poverty line are eligible for reduced lunched.
source.65489706:
COVID-19
Impact on Digital Learning
source.a94cb89c:
Covid-19 has led to students and corporates shifting from Offline Classrooms to Digital Learning.
Although offline Classrooms have their advantages like student interactivity extracurricular activities, interaction with teachers etc. On other hand Digital Learning has its own advantages like 24/7 access to learning, wide range of Learning platforms and students can choose their own teachers whom they are comfortable with.

By combining the data frames, we will compare the impact of covid-19 on various Digital Platforms for various providers across various categories for the Year 2020.
Covid was its peak in the year 2020 and claimed many lives, affected many businesses as well as learning of the students. To prevent loss of lives we made more hospitals, made vaccines. For affected businesses, new business plans were introduced. For Students Digital Learning Platforms gained popularity

Now we will look at some of the aspects on Digital Learning. Digital Learning has seen its major boom during the Covid period when students explored various Digital learning platforms across various categories like online classrooms, digital learning platforms, study tools materials etc.
source.5f6554ea:
| Name | Description |
| :--- | :----------- |
| LP ID| The unique identifier of the product |
| URL | Web Link to the specific product |
| Product Name | Name of the specific product |
| Provider/Company Name | Name of the product provider |
| Sector(s) | Sector of education where the product is used |
| Primary Essential Function | The basic function of the product. There are two layers of labels here. Products are first labeled as one of these three categories: LC = Learning & Curriculum, CM = Classroom Management, and SDO = School & District Operations. Each of these categories have multiple sub-categories with which the products were labeled |
source.16235472:
G. The ENGAGEMENT data

The engagement data are aggregated at school district level and each file of `engagement_data` represents data from one school district. The 4-digit file name represents `district_id`.
source.4f933506:
B. The PROBLEM we have

Education technology company LearnPlatform was founded in 2014 with a mission to expand equitable access to education technology for all students and teachers. LearnPlatform’s comprehensive edtech effectiveness system is used by districts and states to continuously improve the safety, equity, and effectiveness of their educational technology. LearnPlatform does so by generating an evidence basis for what’s working and enacting it to benefit students, teachers, and budgets.
source.d6cbecdb: YouTube is among the top products which is showing a different trend. lets Analyse its affect in Different States month wise.
source.b4bd4405:

After some cleaning, Its time to import some other useful data about the states like Poverty Rate and Median Household Income.

Median Household Income
source.789cbd60:
C. Our Objective

We will work to uncover trends in digital learning. Accomplish this with data analysis about how engagement with digital learning relates to factors like district demographics, broadband access, and state/national level policies and events. Then, we will propose a solution to these educational inequities.

It will be about policies and practices that close the digital divide. With a better understanding of digital learning trends, we may help reverse the long-term learning loss among America’s most vulnerable, making education more equitable.

source.d0636241:
Based on above Indexes and data from NCES website we will replace the missing data with values as below:

  1. Massachusetts -Average household income is much greater than USA average and also poverty level is also lower. Also based on information from NCES data, the missing values can be replaced with range [0.2, 0.4[.
  2. District Of Columbia -Average household income is much greater than USA average but poverty level is in range of USA's average. Based on this and information from NCES , we will impute the missing data with [0.6, 0.8[.
  3. Arizona -Household income and poverty level are in range of USA average, therefore replacing missing with range [0.4, 0.6[.
  4. Tennessee -Household income and poverty level are in range of USA average, therefore replacing missing with range [0.4, 0.6[.
  5. Ohio -Household income and poverty level are in range of USA average, therefore replacing missing with range [0.4, 0.6[.

source.6894324e:
| Name | Description |
| :--- | :----------- |
| district_id | The unique identifier of the school district |
| state | The state where the district resides in |
| locale | NCES locale classification that categorizes U.S. territory into four types of areas: City, Suburban, Town, and Rural. See [Locale Boundaries User's Manual](https://eric.ed.gov/?id=ED577162) for more information. |
| pct_black/hispanic | Percentage of students in the districts identified as Black or Hispanic based on 2018-19 NCES data |
| pct_free/reduced | Percentage of students in the districts eligible for free or reduced-price lunch based on 2018-19 NCES data |
| county_connections_ratio | `ratio` (residential fixed high-speed connections over 200 kbps in at least one direction/households) based on the county level data from FCC From 477 (December 2018 version). See [FCC data](https://www.fcc.gov/form-477-county-data-internet-access-services) for more information. |
| pp_total_raw | Per-pupil total expenditure (sum of local and federal expenditure) from Edunomics Lab's National Education Resource Database on Schools (NERD$) project. The expenditure data are school-by-school, and we use the median value to represent the expenditure of a given school district. |
source.fcb00b98: From above its clear that Google products are performing the best and are among most popular proucts among students. It time to analyse the the Page load events and 100 Page loads for the best performing products and not so good performing products.

| engagement_index | Total page-load events per one thousand students of a given product and on a given day |
source.3c65b6b8: E.1. Data CLEANING
source.f553a8ff:
End of year 2019 covid was spread across the Globle. Many countries start seeing its affect. USA among other countries start seeing the affects of Covid-19.
USA saw its first case on 2020-01-21 in which a Washington resident was diagnosed as covid positive.
National health Emergency was declared in USA on 2020-02-03 which made public aware of the virus and its affects.
After seeing the affects of Covid-19, states of USA start imposing lockdowns. California was the first to impose lockdown starting from 2020-03-19 and South Carolina was last which imposed lockdown starting from 2020-04-07.
It can be seen from above that overall engagement index of USA starts rising after public health emergency was declared in USA. Students started shifting towards the Digital Platforms. During the Summer break both Engagement Index and pct_access saw its major decline. After summer break was over. USA saw its peek in cases during this period. Cases rise to approx 76,000 daily cases. This led to more and more students and schools shiting towards the Digital Platforms for learning only. Many Online platforms gained popularity during this period.
source.ef7c056b: F.1. Exploratory Data Analysis
source.ce6a0df0: Comparison of States performance vs USA's average performance.
source.8e3d12a0:
District of Columbia - The state was observing very less Engagement level of students till the summer break. Seeing the low engagement level of students, State implemented some measure such as distribution of laptops and tablets among the students. Also, provided hotsopts to students who lacked wifi. Local organizations also stepped in to help bridge the digital divide. They distributed funds in terms of grants for student technology and has reserved some funds to help fill technology gaps.
    These measures by State and local organizations helped the students in closing the digital divide, as a result after September, the time at which usually schools reopens, have seen a considerable amount of increase in Engagement level of students in the State. This is a leading example of States interventions to tackle digital divide and encourage Digital learning among students.

source.8e0a885b: Now lets Start Analysing the effect of Covid of Page Load events and Number of Page Loads from Broader aspects like Locale and then we will narrow down the aspects to States, Sectors, Category and Products.
source.6877af09:
Till Now we have seen the Top performing States as well Low performing States, Popular Products amomg Students and Corporates. We have also seen the Poverty levels as well Income of States.

Now its time to answer few questions.
source.848f8ca1: County connections ratio is monotonoic in nature and have same value for each data point. Therefore, we will not use County connections Ratio in our Analysis. Therefore lets drop the connections columns.
source.9ad660cf: Replacing the missing values in engagement_index and pct_access with 0.
source.2b6d0a63:
How does student engagement with online learning platforms relate to different geography? Demographic context (e.g., race/ethnicity, ESL, learning disability)? Learning context? Socioeconomic status?
We have seen the Demographic Comparison of all States, in which Black/Hispanic, Eligibility for free/reduced lunch, expenditure per pupil, poverty level of state and median household income of states. Lets make some inferences about the Top performing States as well as not so good performing States and comapre these indexes of these states.

  1. Arizona- This is among the Top Performing State having page load events much higher as compared to other states. Percentage of Black/Hispanic is much above the Country’s average. Similarly, Students eligible for free/reduced lunches are also high than Country’s average. However, State is spending less on its students. Also poverty level is state is also on higher side with median household income on lower side. On Contrary, Arizona is all covered with City only.
  2. New York- New York also among the top States with page load events higher as compared to some states. There was slight drop in Page load events as we progressed through the year, with lesser on later phase of the year. Surprisingly, New York’s average household income is less than Country’s average and is slightly having more poverty level among people. But State is spending much higher on its students for their development. Black/Hispanic percentage is very less as compared to other states and students eligible for free/reduced lunch were comparable to Country’s average.

We have seen some Top performing states. Now lets have alook at Not so good performmg states such as

  1. Utah- Utah is among the states performing bad on page load events index. Although it is performing bad on page load indexes, but median household income of state is higher as compared as compared to Country’s average with least amount of people living in poverty next to New Hampshire. Keeping in view of average household income, state also spends less on the people. Therefore, students eligible for free/reduced lunches are also very less. Also, Black/Hispanic percentage is also less compared to other states. State is mostly covered with suburb with least amount of rural areas.
  2. Tennessee- This state is also among the states performing bad on page load events index. On contrary to Utah, median household income is less and people living in poverty are more. Expenditure by State on its students is also less. Because more people are living in poverty with less median household income, students eligible for free/reduced lunch are more. Tennessee also having very less amount of Black/Hispanic people. State is equally covered with Rural and Suburb.

Based on observations form few states above we can see that It's the states policies which determines the engagement level of students. Demographics also playing a role but we can see that some states being on poorer side (New York) based on data, performing good whereas Utah among the richer state with higher household income in performing bad on page load events.

Now its time to look at another probale aspect which can determine engagement_level of students.
source.2b03d1ca: Now lets have a look at the top products of Learning Curriculum Category as it has very large number of Products to offer.

  1. Sectors have 20 missing values and their corresponding Primary Essential Function is also null. There is a relation between null values of Sectors and Primary Essential Function. So lets keep the null values as it is.
  2. Around 10% of data values are missing for Sector and Primary Essential function. Only 1 is missing for Provider.
  3. Lets bifurcate the Primary Essential Function column.

  1. Major Products belong to Corporate Sector followed by prek12; higher edu; corporate sector.
